Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; rude modelling; incised details on the back; underside decorated (likely stamped) with hieroglyphic inscription, with neb-basket sign surmounted by owl and sun-disc to left; longitudinally pierced; thick pale blue glaze.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The owl sign is often associated on Naukratite scarabs and scaraboids with solar symbols (see example of an owl between an obelisk and sun-disc in Gorton 1996, 103, no. 84) or other sacred signs (Maat feather, ankh sign: Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, 42; Gorton 1996, 104). Though the hieroglyphic signs have often just some magical value, it seems plausible that this is a cryptographic reading for the name of Amun-Ra. This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 103-107, type XXVIII B, see especially 71-88 for this piece). For a similar association of signs on other scarabs from Naukratis: BM 1886,0401.1667 and Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-EA.908. Variant of the same motif on scarabs and scaraboids from the Scarab Factory (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming): Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 99-104; Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, 42. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 101) (same motif but in Egyptian blue)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.059) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5765 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
